title: Thinking critically about digital data collection: Twitter and beyond
segmentation: So.
You have to listen to another political scientist this afternoon.

I apologize, this is a project that I am working on with my two other colleagues listed listed here under Shorts and Daniel Stockman and what I'm going to present to you today is a piece of a much larger project.

I'll talk a bit more towards the end about the other things that we're doing with this, but whenever I give this presentation, I feel a bit bad because I'm the person who's coming in to pour cold water.
On the room.

When I say thinking critically about digital data collection, I'm pretty critical about the way most digital data collection up to now has been done, and I'm going to be focusing primarily on Twitter, but I'll talk at the end about the implications of some of the findings that we have for digital data collection beyond Twitter as well.
So let me give you just a bit of a bit of background to help you understand how I came to this project in the 1st place.
I am a social scientist first and foremost and I had an interest in studying the 2014 protests that were happening in Hong Kong.
They're often referred to as the umbrella protests, and I collected a great deal of Twitter data and my colleague Daniel Stockman was collecting microblog data from several platforms in China.
At the same time, and as I started digging into the Twitter data, I realized there was a fundamental problem here and that was I didn't understand what I actually had.
I knew I had Twitter data, but I didn't know what that meant.
How was it?
How representative was it of Twitter as a whole, and what I found among social scientists in particular is that they, and as I began the process myself.
Take the tools that others have presented to us or we partner with those who are more technically proficient than we are, and we just sort of put it out there and let everyone else write.
Do it for us and trust that the data that we're getting back is somehow good.
So my question here was what data do I actually have in my hands?
And really, is it good?
Data in particular?
Is it biased in some way?
So I started digging into this and trying to understand this question really.
At the most basic level, what are we observing through this Twitter data that I have?
And why are we observing this particular data?
There are a number of ways, I think most of you likely understand of collecting Twitter data.
Before I go into much depth here, I would just like to take a brief, really quick show of hands.
How many of you would say that you feel very comfortable?
You know a lot about the Twitter API's?

OK, not quite half of the room so and some of those are even sort of maybe Ish hands, so I'm going to try and find a midway point between giving you lots and lots of details that some people in the room will already know and also giving you some of the basics because not everyone does know everything clearly about this.
So there are a number of different application programming interfaces that Twitter provides, some public, some not public.
What is commonly referred to as the firehose for those who have used Twitter data or likely to know that this is incredibly cost prohibitive.
Now.
In this slide I'm just going to go through really basic overview of the API's and then I'll talk in more detail about each of them in just a minute.
There's the streaming API, which, like the fire hose.
Is real time data, but it is a sample of the fire hose, so the fire hose is in theory every tweet in real time that's being produced on Twitter.

The streaming API is some sample of that data, but Twitter doesn't document for us very well what that means, and in some instances it may be that the stream actually is 100% of the firehose, but we don't have a whole lot of knowledge about when that's the case.
Whether it's the case in the first place.
The search API is nested within the larger REST API.
This is also a public API freely available to use, and it's basically a historical search, but it has very significant limitations and I'll talk about those at length in just one minute.
And finally, there's the historical Archive, which is not an API at all.
It is an archive of previous tweets, right beginning with June 2006 when Twitter actually.
Opened began its operations, but it's not a true archive because any tweet that is deleted by user or by Twitter itself for any reason disappears from the historical archive.

So when I'm talking to people about the different ways that you can collect Twitter data, I'm actually surprised how many I run into who believe that when they're using archive data, they've actually got everything right that's relevant to their particular interest on that topic.
That it's a true historical archive that nothing has decayed.
Nothing is disappeared.
But that's simply not true.
So now let's talk a bit more about the streaming API an I'm going to talk specifically about how we might use each of these API's to collect data based on keyword queries.
For those of you who use the API's you know full well that there are multiple ways that you can query the API's.
The search API in particular, you can use to collect the full timeline of someones tweets within some limitations.
But what I'm interested in here is when we do research using particular keyword queries, how does that data come back to us?
It is the streaming API is as I just mentioned, a real time capture and it can capture up to 1%.
Of all global volume.

So we know for certain Twitter tells us in its documentation that they will rate limit right the return of our data if the query parameters that we've entered go above 1% of all global Twitter volume at a given moment in time.

So if an issue or event is particularly popular, it's very likely that you're going to be rate limited because the volume of that issue or event that you're querying is much higher than or even slightly higher than 1% of global volume.

This is also a problem when my fellow countrymen and women go to sleep or on vacation, so when Americans decrease their volume of tweeting, it's much more likely that those of us trying to capture the data are going to get rate limited.
Because the overall volume of 20 of tweets being produced is depressed, Americans are still by far the highest volume users of Twitter.
So when we go on vacation or go to sleep.
It's more difficult to get tweets as researchers.
One thing to know about the streaming API and this is something that a lot of people don't talk about too much.
But when we query the various APIs it actually queries different parts of a tweet.
So for the streaming API, if you put in hashtag I don't know.
Let's say let's hashtag mclerran plus right?
The streaming API will query the text of a tweet.
It will look for any hashtags it would query at mentions and it will query URLs.
So if there happens to be a URL attached to a tweet that has Claire and plus in it, it will return that tweet even if it doesn't have the hashtag or Claire.
And plus in the text.

This is the same as querying fire hose through the powertrack functionality that is not public that must be paid for and you have to go through a third party provider to get, but it's the exact same fields that the powertrack queries for you.
Then we have the search API, which is probably at least for social scientists.
The most commonly used API, and this is highly problematic as I'll show you pretty soon here.
When you're doing keyword queries, it is more or less ahistorical capture.
You can actually set up the capture in a way using the search API.
That sort of acts like the stream, but it is ultimately a historical capture.
It queries only the text of a tweet.
So if you want claren plus from URLs, you're not going to get it using the search API.
And it has extremely significant limitations.
First, you can only return up to 18,000 tweets over the last, approximately 7 to 10 day.
You never know exactly how many days you're going to get.
And that's whichever limit is reached first.
You can do up to 180 calls every 15 minutes.
And.
Well, this is really I'm double clicking here without realizing it.

It captures significantly less than 100% of the tweets, So what Twitter tells us very vaguely in its API documentation is that it will return quote, unquote, top, tweets, what the heck that means is anybody's guess.
That's actually a piece of what I'm trying to research here.
All Twitter tells us is these are top tweets.
The archive, as I mentioned before, is not an archive at all, and it is not truly a record of all tweets.
Now, Interestingly, the terms of service for Twitter use actually required that every single one of us that uses Twitter data ourselves remove any deleted tweets from our own datasets.
Logistically that is going to be impossible for essentially everyone using Twitter data.
But when we use it, these are the terms that we agreed to.

There's been a very limited amount of previous research that asks the sorts of questions that we're asking here that examines essentially how much bias or how different the various APIs are from one another.
So Driscoll and Walker andmore stutter at all are probably of the literature that I've looked at.
They are certainly the best.
Peace is the best studies that are out there and they compare the fire hose to the streaming API.

Driscoll and Walker look particularly at high and medium volume events, so they queried two particular hashtags and keywords, one for an event that they expected to be to have lots and lots of volume, and so they really expected rate limits to come in and medium volume events.
But all they did was compare tweet counts.
So they looked at for the firehose.
How many tweets did we get an then for the stream, how did we?
How many did we get?
That's a good start, but it really is only a start.

More stutter at all went a bit further, but they only looked at one medium volume event and they examined the differences between the fire hose in the stream in terms of the top hashtags that were captured in the two datasets.
They compared topic analysis results and they looked at a number of network centrality measures from social network analysis and what they found.
I mean, what Driscoll and Walker found was that there are clear differences between the number of tweets that you get back from the stream versus the firehose.

What more stutter at all found is that if we do any of these types of analysis, especially when things are rate limited, but even when they're not, we're probably probably got some problems, and that's the bottom line.
But we wanted to take this even further, so we collected a common set of six hashtags related to the Hong Kong protests from 2014, and we collected them for the first half of October 2014.
This is when the protests were really at their height.

And we tried to get the data from the power track, but unfortunately at 2 two points during our data collection there was a pretty major gnip outage and we couldn't actually get the correct firehose data.
So we wound up purchasing it from the archive.
Several days later.
Have you paid attention to what I just said?
The archive is not perfect and that tweets are often deleted, so we don't have a true.
In this sense, we don't have a true population.
Of the data, but we come quite close and I'll tell you a bit later about how we're doing additional analysis where we do actually have the perfect, more or less perfect data that we want.
From the archive we gathered over 500,000 tweets.
Then we used Ticat to capture the from the streaming API using the same query of these six hashtags and during this.
During this 15 day.
So we actually had a longer period that we looked at overall, But during this 15 day.
There are no rate limits whatsoever, so we can speak about our results being during a totally non rate limited.
There we got about 470,000 tweets, or roughly 85% of the archive.
Now remember the archive.

Has there been some tweets that are deleted and so we do have a bit of a problem where there would likely be more tweets that we're not seeing here, but also this data sets have not a large number, but some tweets that appear in the streaming data set and not in the archive because they were later deleted.
And then finally we used the usdcad again to query the search API and collected about 255 thousand tweets or roughly 46% of the archive data.
Then we perform 2 forms of analysis here.

The first question that we asked is is like is biased likely to be introduced when the data is collected using either API and as we started out with the analysis we did some things that were similar to what more stutter at all did.
So our first type of valuation, we did several types of valuation.
I'm going to focus on this one here.

Is a kendalls Tau correlation of the top mentions and usernames across the data set, so this Kendall's Tau for those who aren't familiar just looks at ranked lists of things and compares across those rankings to see how correlated they are to one another.
So you take the top ten, let's say hashtags that appear in one data set and ask how closely, how close is that to the top ten hashtags that appear in other datasets?
The archive was the baseline in each case.
And as you'll see, in just a moment, the simple answer is that bias appears to be highly likely.
Now, Kendall's Tau doesn't actually give us a direct measure of bias.
It gives us a measure of error.
So in a later step we actually get a bias more clearly.

But what I'm about to show you with these numbers is the level of error is so high that it would be in many instances that it would be pretty difficult for us to even make the case that bias couldn't be here.
We'd very strongly suspected.
So let's begin with the mentions data.
Here's the top ten mentions that were that appeared top 2550 and so on through the top 1000.
And if we compare the archive to the stream, we see that for the top ten we get about a .78 degree of correlation.
For some, that might be acceptable, but for many researchers, for a lot of research questions, that's simply not going to be appropriate.
That is the lowest level, but the highest that we get is what here in the top?
Oh no, sorry, the top 25 at about 8:00, five level of correlation.
Results are much worse for comparison between the archive and the search results.
This very first number for the top 10 is dramatically low.
.24 correlation is pretty abysmal.
The highest we ever get with this data set is .61.
So just not satisfactory.
With the usernames, the results are fairly similar, although at one point the stream performs quite a bit better, reaches the .9 correlation.
For some, this may now be acceptable, but again the search doesn't do especially well.
Nothing as low as this .24, but we're still looking at pretty low levels of correlation.
It would be really difficult.
To suggest that bias isn't going to appear here.

But in order to more directly test whether there is bias, we actually ran a number of regression models where we asked is there a systematic difference between the factors that characterize the types of tweets that we get in the archive compared to the two streaming and search API's?
The two public APIs?
So we did it logit regression analysis, where the dependent variable was simply does it appear we took all of the archived tweets and we simply said does it appear in the search API?
Doesn't appear in the streaming API.
And then we were interested in two broad sets of tweet characteristics.
The first of those were the user characteristic variables.
So, for example, we asked questions about how prolific.
The Twitter user is, so someone who's actually tweeting this if they have lots and lots of tweets, is it possible that Twitter is prioritizing them and their content?
Are they favoring heavy users?
How popular is the user here?
We measure this using the simple follower count, right?
So the hypothesis would be that Twitter is more likely to privilege those who are actually much more popular on the platform itself.

We had another variable for how engaged the user was, so in this sense, how many friends does a person have and one of the things we were trying to innocence proxy here was bought detection because we know right that frequently bots have a huge discrepancy in follower versus friends count, right?
They don't so.
And we know that this is actually right.
There's been discussion publicly about Twitter using some of these metrics to try and at least help it detect bots.
Then we looked at tweet characteristic variables.
So all of this was about the person who's tweeting him or herself.
Then we actually looked at the content of the tweet.
And the first variable here is fairly straightforward.
We call this originality, so it's just a dummy variable for whether it's an original tweet or a retweet.
Second engagement with others.

So might it be a possibility that Twitter prioritizes or privileges those tweets where we happen to be reaching out to a lot of other Twitter users and we get at this by simply counting the number of mentions that appear in the body of a tweet.
Then there's engagement in discourse.
So here we're starting to think about the kind of richness of the content of a tweet.
And if people are actually trying to get involved in a more public right body of discussion by including hashtags.
So our measure here is a count of the number of hashtags that appear in the body of a tweet.
And finally getting at content richness in terms of multimedia.
So again, does Twitter privilege?
Those tweets that have a URL that have a picture that have a gift of some sort there?
And what I did in this case was I ran 40 different logit models, being completely transparent, right?
There is no theory behind this.
This is a straight up datamining endeavour.
I was looking for models that ran the best so I did a stepwise test of all of those eight variables and then plausable interactions between them.
What I actually found was the simplest models.
Proved the best, so those that didn't include interaction terms.
Now here are results again.
I'm double clicking.
Let's start with this one.
This is a comparison of the archive to the search results and not surprisingly, because we're dealing with high volume data, we have statistical significance for almost everything.
So what will be interested in a highlight here in just a minute are the odds ratios the same thing with the streaming API?
So you can just very quickly eyeball this and see that we reach statistical significance for most.
Right of our coefficients, but the.

Odds ratios are really what tell us the most here, so these are the three variables in the search data where there is some substantial difference between meaningful difference between those tweets that appear in the search API versus those that appeared in the archive.
Retweets are much less likely to appear in the search API, so indeed Twitter is privileging original tweets over retweets.
Mentions counts actually much to my surprise, the higher the number of mentions, the less likely a tweet is to appear in the search API.
Now I need to do some additional analysis on this.
I think what's probably driving this finding.
Is it is I suspect that Twitter is deprioritising conversations where people are replying to one another.
So I need to take a quick look and see if indeed I add a variable to control for those tweets that are conversations that are replies.
If this continues to hold, haven't had a chance to do that yet.
The hashtag count, right?
The more hashtags that are in there, the more likely a tweet is to appear in the search API results.
All.
Are all fairly similar results for the stream that was in and of itself something that was surprising to me.
I thought that there would be pretty substantial differences between the two, but that's not what I found.
So again, retweets are deprioritized, but look at the dramatic difference here, right?
So they are importantly deprioritized in the search, but even more so in the streaming API.
This has really significant implications for.
Any of us doing analysis that relies on retweets?
The mentions count is the same As for the search API.
The hashtag count is the same here though.
We have quite a substantial difference for the multimedia variable, so the stream really prioritizes tweets that have a rich multimedia content.
URLs, videos, and the like.
Now.
What does this lead us to?
And I put in parentheses here that we're talking about tentative conclusions.
These are really tentative at this point because as I said, the data aren't perfect, right?
There are fairly good approximation, but they're not perfect yet.
And as I promised, I'll tell you very shortly about the new data that we're looking at.
But what this initial data seems to suggest to us is that content matters for Twitter and its API's.
So.
It's the actual.
You know content, it's the richness.
It's the originality.
It's the tweet itself that seems to matter.
Users very much to my surprise, did not matter in this analysis.

I actually expected just sort of instinctively that it was going to be the exact opposite that Twitter was really going to prioritize popular heavy users, but it's actually about the content, at least in this part of the analysis.
Oh, come on.

OK, So what this means is that we as researchers, when we're using either of the public APIs, are looking at what we might call especially rich content, and that in and of itself has implications for, particularly when we're doing natural language processing, analysis has fairly significant implications for how we understand how representative the samples that we have are of the larger population.
Now I say all of this with the qualification that we know the algorithms are constantly changing.
For Twitter's public APIs.
And this data is from 2014.
Since then, Twitter has publicly announced that they've made major changes, right?
They don't announce the small changes.
They don't tell us about the small changes, but occasionally they announce large changes.
And we know that quite recently, right, there have been pretty dramatic timeline changes that are also likely to be taken into account in the API's, right?
And the data that they return.
There's also been more emphasis in the recent year or so on improving the verified user status.
So as Twitter has come under increasing public pressure to decrease the abuse and harassment and general nastiness that we all see on the platform, these sorts of things are likely to impact right?
What data it ultimately?
Elects to push out to consumer users to researchers like ourselves.
Now I want to be really careful, right?
As I'm drawing these conclusions because frequently when I give this talk, people walk away with Rebecca's, been telling us that Twitter is evil, right?
And it's trying to harm researchers around the world, right?
It's a big evil company with all its proprietary interests, and it won't tell us what it's really doing, right?
It's trying to sabotage us.
That's not what I actually think is happening, particularly because we found that the content matters.
I think what's going on this is just my hypothesis, but what I think is going on is pretty easy to understand from Twitter's perspectives.
Perspective think about the fact that retweets right are deprioritized, especially when we've got high volume.
Within the Twitter system and the algorithm has to generate more and more data.
One of the easiest kind of technical things that they can do to very dramatically reduce that data is simply to push out a bunch of the retweets.
One very simple rule that will dramatically change the infrastructural.
Needs right that Twitter has as the platform.
Now as I said, where continuing this analysis on new data which is better than the old data.
We have very large data set from Trump's.

Inauguration we for 8 hours collected all mentions of at realdonaldtrump using the fire hose, the powertrack firehose, and then we did the in real time collection on the stream and did historical search capture as well.
Then we have collected three datasets that are focused on excuse me are focused on hashtags.
The first one, which was a very high volume and we expect it to be high volume event because Twitter actually advertised this hashtag.
So this was during Donald Trump's first address to con to Congress.
What we normally think of is a state of the Union, but in the very first one, the president gives a joint session address rather than state of the Union.
And indeed afterwards, Twitter announced that it was the highest volume during the speech.
They had the highest volume that they have ever had in the history of the platform.
Our second hashtag is a HCA.
the American Health Care Act and we collected this during the first failed attempt to get this legislation get this bill to the House floor.
And then finally our low volume event was the hashtag jobs report.
So the 1st of every month the US Labor Department releases its monthly jobs report for the month previous and tells us how many jobs have been gained or lost.
So it's an identifiable event but low volume.
We don't expect any rate limits.
Indeed for real at Realdonaldtrump and joint session we were rate limited in the streaming API the entire time.
For HCA, we were rate limited towards the end where it started to become clear that they weren't going to get anything on the floor and everybody started talking about it.
Jobs report we never had any rate limits.
I don't have lots of results.

We it's going to take time for us to process all of this, but what I can tell you is that our preliminary findings are really supporting everything that we found before every single one of the problems that I just talked to you about persist across all the datasets, including most interesting Lee, our low volume jobs report data set.
We're not getting on either the stream or the search, even though we're not rate limited, we're not getting 100%.
Of the data.
And biases continue to persist.
Now let's think about how this applies beyond Twitter.
As I've heard as I've already discussed, with a number of people in the room, we all know, right?
the Twitter data is so popular because it does provide public APIs we can get our hands on some real data, right?
And high volumes of it.
Other platforms, their API's are far more restrictive.
Facebook, Reddit.
Much much more restrictive than Twitter.
We simply don't know what we don't know about any of these datasets.
So with Twitter we can spend, as I've done a lot of money to buy the full population of data and compare it to the data from the APIs with these other platforms.
We can't.
But even with the Twitter example, right, as I told you, I'm just data mining with my logit regression analysis.
I'm essentially throwing darts.
In the dark at these things, here are the things that I think might be interesting that might play into Twitter's calculations, but I don't really know.

Ultimately, I don't know what I don't know here, and it's even worse for other platforms than it is for Twitter, because at least Twitter throws out kind of little Nuggets for us every once in awhile.
Another thing that I think is incredibly important for everyone to keep in mind is that the moment of capture always matters for us.
It matters in terms of I thought I had a couple of sub points below there.
But it matters in terms of data decay, and it matters in terms of metadata in fact.
That I think about it, but this slide has it.
Yes, so I wanted to really highlight this last point.
When we capture matters.
In terms of data decay.
As I said, with the historical archive, we know for Twitter that data disappears.
There's been like one or two basic studies that have looked at this outside of Twitter and generally tend to find that digital data right at any spot.
Whether we're talking social media or in some general Internet environment, digital data tends to decay about 10% in the first year.
Research that I'm doing on Twitter right now.
Suggest that most of that happens in the initial hours and days that actually very quickly we lose a big chunk and then it slows dramatically after that.
But that means if what we really need is right, the data from that moment, we have to be ready to get it in that moment.
2nd, we need to think about the implications of data timing of data collection for the metadata that we gather.
So for example, if we're looking at Facebook posts and perhaps we're looking at one month period, right?
If we collect data at the end of that month and we're looking at things like the number of likes on a post or even the number of comments, or the types of comments that develop.

That metadata is going to be impacted by the moment that we've chosen to capture, so the posts that have been there for that whole month have more time together that the likes or the comments or whatever.
Then those that have been posted more recently.
And I think that's where I'd like to leave things for you today.
So thank you for your time and attention.
And feel free to.
Well, I'm looking forward to additional conversations into questions.
And feel free to send me nasty messages on either of these venues.
Thank you.
